timeline.bodyText:
Nipick: Can we pass the elapsed time directly so we don't use ActorClock directly here? Just seems strange to couple this to the ActorClock here
EDIT: same below I guess
timeline.author: npepinpe

timeline.bodyText: Weren't you the one who asked not to create new column families? 😜
timeline.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText: Jep but we didn't decided against it so 🤷‍♂️
replies.author: Zelldon

timeline.bodyText:
Hm, don't know how I feel about using the ActorClock as a default, which has different behaviour based on which thread calls it 😅
Also, what about existing instances? Will this metric give me initially incredibly fast jobs since creation time will be instantiated with the current timestamp? 😅
timeline.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText:
Hm, don't know how I feel about using the ActorClock as a default, which has different behaviour based on which thread calls it sweat_smile

What is the alternative? You want to use system time? I mean we did in our test but actually the clock was introduced to avoid calling system time to often.

Also, what about existing instances? Will this metric give me initially incredibly fast jobs since creation time will be instantiated with the current timestamp?

dont get this question to be honest
replies.author: Zelldon

timeline.message: chore(monitor): add latency metrics to dashboard

timeline.bodyText:
Nitpick: do we need to know from the variable name that it is a tree map? I guess creationTimeToJobKeyNavigableMap doesn't have the same ring ;) I guess I'm just surprised since we don't really want to care about the concrete time except when creating it 🤷‍♂️
Just a nitpick, feel free to ignore
timeline.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText:
I added the TreeMap just to know that we can use these subMap stuff, but yes NavigableMap would also be ok.

I guess I'm just surprised since we don't really want to care about the concrete time except when creating it man_shrugging

Sorry but I don't get this comment.
replies.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText: Sorry, typo, I meant to write concrete type not concrete time haha, as treeMap the concrete type is part of the name 😅
replies.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText: Haha that makes much more sense😀👍
replies.author: Zelldon

timeline.bodyText: Nitpick: any reason to use the concrete type instead of Map<Long, Long>?
timeline.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText: Actually yes because I wanted to avoid the auto boxing.
replies.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText: Ah, right, doing a get(Long) would auto-box, true 👍 Though I wonder if the JIT would optimize if we did final long l = map.get(1) since we always auto-box/auto-unbox 🤔
replies.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText: I don't think so since you use different method then
replies.author: Zelldon

timeline.bodyText: How likely is it to get collision? If we write a batch of follow up events, it's likely they all have the same creation time, no? Especially if we use the ActorClock? Could we end up with "garbage" over time? I put it in quotes since technically we should eventually see the completion record for that entity, but still.
timeline.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText:
If we write a batch of follow up events, it's likely they all have the same creation time, no?

I think they have the same time on a batch.

Could we end up with "garbage" over time? I put it in quotes since technically we should eventually see the completion record for that entity, but still.

Can you elaborate on that?
replies.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText: So I add a bunch of keys with the same creation time into the creationTimeToJobKeyTreeMap (or the other one). It's a map, so it only saves the latest value, no? So when I clean up, I actually only clean up that value, not any of the others from the map? Or am I missing something?
replies.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText: Ok got what you mean, but everything which is stored is not created due to batches. So job created for example is not written in a batch and also the workflow instance creation is not.
replies.author: Zelldon

replies.bodyText: Ah true, we only store for processes and jobs, so they are never part of a batch (I think? Can't remember how a multi-instance call activity would look like 😅)
replies.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText: Even if multi instances creates multiple jobs the CREATED will be written again one by one 🙂 so should be fine
replies.author: Zelldon

timeline.author: npepinpe
npepinpe

replies.bodyText: Hm not sure anymore I think because it is a helper method and it can also moved elsewhere
replies.author: Zelldon

timeline.author: npepinpe

timeline.bodyText: Nit: Could we also just check if recordValue.getBpmnElementType() == BpmnElementType.PROCESS? I think this is how we do it in WorkflowInstanceMetrics
timeline.author: npepinpe

replies.bodyText: Ah yes thanks always forget this elementType thing 😅
replies.author: Zelldon

timeline.message:
chore(broker): add metric exporter

The execution metric exporter will collect informations based on the seen records
and publish latency metric like:

 * process execution time, shows the time between creating and completing/terminating a workflow instance
 * job activation time, shows the time between creating an job and activating it
 * job lifetime, show the time between creating an job and completing it

As it makes more sense for short running process and not on all use cases it is disabled by default.
We can enabled it for example with a env variable, which we will do with
out benchmark setup. For performance analysis the metrics are quite
interesting. We moved these metrics into an exporter, such that we not
have this in our current state (db) since it is not always needed and
can easily be extended.
